who violently sweep your house

He may be clearing you out
for some new delight.

meet them at the door laughing,
and invite them in.

because each has been sent
as a guide from beyond.

[22/06/2025, 1:32:14â€¯AM] Amir Ariff: The poem â€œThe Guest Houseâ€ by Rumi, a 13th-century Persian poet and Sufi mystic, is a metaphorical piece about the human experienceâ€”especially our emotions and states of mind.

Hereâ€™s a breakdown of its core meaning:

â¸»

ğŸ’¡ Main Idea:

Your mind and soul are like a guest house.
Every day, new â€œguestsâ€ (emotions, experiences, thoughts) arriveâ€”joy, sadness, anger, shame, excitement, etc.

Rather than resisting or judging these feelings, welcome them all, even the painful ones. Why? Because each has something to teach you.

â¸»

ğŸ§˜â€â™‚ï¸ Spiritual Message:
	â€¢	Emotions are temporary visitors. Donâ€™t cling to them or shut them out.
	â€¢	Suffering and discomfort are often the bearers of important inner growth.
	â€¢	Life is a series of arrivals and departuresâ€”embracing all of them brings peace and understanding.

â¸»

ğŸ“Œ Key Lines & Interpretation:

â€œThis being human is a guest house.â€
Your soul is open to many visitorsâ€”just like a guest house.

â€œA joy, a depression, a meanness, some momentary awareness comes as an unexpected visitor.â€
Each emotion or thought, even if unpleasant, has a role.

â€œWelcome and entertain them all!â€
Donâ€™t resist your feelingsâ€”acknowledge and accept them.

â€œBe grateful for whoever comes, because each has been sent as a guide from beyond.â€
Even your darkest moments have valueâ€”they are teachers or guides for your personal journey.

â¸»

ğŸ§­ Life Application:
	â€¢	When you feel overwhelmed by anxiety or sadness, remember: itâ€™s just a visitor, not a permanent resident.
	â€¢	Practice mindfulness and non-judgmental awarenessâ€”let your emotions flow through you, not define you.
	â€¢	Every life experience, good or bad, contributes to your growth and resilience.

â¸»

[14/07/2025, 1:40:37â€¯PM] Amir Ariff: Below is a quickâ€reference snapshot of what you can expect to pay for senior-care options in Malaysia in 2025.  All figures are per person, per month unless stated otherwise, and assume a long-stay arrangement (minimum one month).  One-off deposits of 1â€“3 monthsâ€™ fees are common; some purpose-built retirement villages also require a refundable lump-sum lease of RM 300 k â€“ 600 k.

Care setting (level of help)	Typical fee range	Whatâ€™s usually included	Recent price examples*
Basic nursing home / old-folks home (shared room, nurse on call)	RM 1,500 â€“ 2,800	Bed & board, basic ADL assistance, simple medical checks	Low-dependency packages start ~RM 2,950 (KL)  ï¿¼
Mid-range nursing home (24 h nurses, doctor rounds, physio)	RM 3,000 â€“ 5,000	24 h care, all meals, therapy area, activities	Mid-tier homes quote RM 3â€“5 k  ï¿¼ ï¿¼
High-dependency / medical nursing (ICU-style beds, specialised rehab)	RM 5,000 â€“ 7,500	1:4 nurse ratio or better, wound/PEG care, physio, OT	High-dependency beds RM 3,950 â€“ 6,000+ depending on location  ï¿¼ ï¿¼
Assisted-living unit (own studio/1-bed, help on demand)	RM 4,000 â€“ 7,000	Furnished unit, housekeeping, two meals, nurse call button, social programme	Care Concierge â€œThe Mansionâ€ from RM 4 k; Millennia Village 1-bed ~RM 3,500 â€“ 4,800  ï¿¼ ï¿¼
Premium retirement resort (hotel-style, full amenities)	RM 8,800 â€“ 10,000+	Private suite, concierge, all meals, daily activities, on-site clinic	Sunway Sanctuary: RM 8,800 (independent) / RM 9,600 (assisted)  ï¿¼ ï¿¼
Senior day-care centre (8 am â€“ 6 pm, Mon-Sat)	RM 120 â€“ 270 per day	Meals, activities, nurse supervision	Komune Care RM 125/day; Care Concierge RM 270/day  ï¿¼
Live-in home-care aide (carer stays with elder)	RM 235 â€“ 260 per day	24 h companionship & basic nursing, meals extra	Care Concierge RM 235/day  ï¿¼
Hourly home-care visit	RM 30 â€“ 40 per hour	Personal care, medication, light physio	Homage: RM 30â€“36/hour  ï¿¼
Government-run welfare homes (Rumah Seri Kenangan, Rumah Ehsan)	Free (means-tested; long wait-list)	Basic dormitory living, meals, basic nursing	Ministry of Women, Family & Community Development data

*Examples shown are the latest published prices (September 2024 â€“ February 2025).  Individual homes adjust fees annually for inflation and staffing costs.

â¸»

Key factors that move the price
	1.	Dependency level â€“ The more hands-on nursing or rehab required, the steeper the bill.
	2.	Location â€“ Klang Valley and Penang cost 10-25 % more than smaller cities such as Melaka or Kota Bharu.  ï¿¼
	3.	Room type â€“ Private or ensuite rooms command a 20-40 % premium over shared wards.
	4.	Care ratios & amenities â€“ Facilities offering 1:3 nurse ratios, on-site physio gyms, or hotel-style dining sit at the upper end.
	5.	Optional add-ons â€“ Adult diapers, night-duty caregivers, specialist therapies, and medical consumables are often billed separately (RM 200 â€“ 1,000 +/month).

â¸»

Quick budgeting rules of thumb

Scenario	Budget at least
Elder with low medical needs, small-town home	RM 2 k/month
Moderate care, Klang Valley private home	RM 4 â€“ 5 k/month
High-dependency dementia care	RM 6 â€“ 8 k/month
Resort-style independent living (KL or Penang)	RM 9 â€“ 11 k/month


â¸»

Tips when short-listing a home
	â€¢	Visit during meal or therapy times to see staff-to-resident interaction.
	â€¢	Ask for the itemised fee schedule (look out for hidden charges such as catheter changes or ambulance transfers).
	â€¢	Check staff credentials â€“ Are nurses registered with the Malaysian Nursing Board?
	â€¢	Read recent inspection reports (Jabatan Kebajikan Masyarakat issues annual licences).
	â€¢	Negotiate trial stays â€“ Many homes allow a one-week paid trial before committing to long-term contracts.

Need location-specific suggestions or help comparing homes?  Let me know the city and level of care, and I can narrow the list further.

as an unexpected visitor.

Even if theyâ€™re a crowd of sorrows,
who violently sweep your house
empty of its furniture,

He may be clearing you out
for some new delight.

because each has been sent

[28/07/2025, 10:36:01â€¯AM] Amir Ariff: Rumi â€“ â€œThe Guest Houseâ€ (meaning, in simple words)
	â€¢	Rumi says: being human is like running a guest house.
Every day, new â€œguestsâ€ (feelings) arriveâ€”joy, sadness, anger, shame, anxiety.
	â€¢	Welcome them all, even the painful ones. Donâ€™t fight or judge them.
Each emotion comes with a message and can clear space inside you for deeper joy or wisdom.
	â€¢	Feelings are temporary visitors. If you treat them with respect and curiosity, they pass through and you grow more compassionate, grounded, and free.
	â€¢	Itâ€™s a practice of mindfulness and acceptance: notice, allow, learn, and let go.

â¸»

How to use it in life
	1.	When a tough feeling shows up, say: â€œAh, a guest is here.â€
	2.	Breathe, feel it in the body, donâ€™t push it away.
	3.	Ask: â€œWhat is this teaching me?â€
	4.	Let it leave when itâ€™s ready.

**Common â€œbarriersâ€:**

* Fear of rejection or abandonment
* Old comparisons/ex memories
* Needing control / perfection

* Numbness from stress or burnout

[28/07/2025, 5:34:58â€¯PM] Ayunni: Taaruf (ØªØ¹ÙØ§Ø±ÙÙ) is an Arabic word that means â€œgetting to know one another.â€ In the context of relationships, especially in Islamic or Muslim cultures, taaruf refers to the formal, respectful process of getting to know a potential spouse with the intention of marriage â€” but without dating or romantic involvement in the Western sense.

Key features of Taaruf:
	1.	Marriage-focused â€“ Itâ€™s done with the clear intention of exploring marriage, not casual dating.
	2.	Halal (permissible) â€“ Interactions are done in a way that aligns with Islamic values: modesty, boundaries, and sincerity.
	3.	Guided or accompanied â€“ Often involves a wali (guardian), family, or a third party like a matchmaker or ustaz/ustazah to avoid seclusion or inappropriate closeness.
	4.	Open conversations â€“ Both parties ask about values, goals, family background, compatibility, religious commitment, etc.
	5.	Short and purposeful â€“ Itâ€™s not meant to drag on for years. If compatible, the couple proceeds to engagement (khitbah) and eventually nikah (marriage).

[01/08/2025, 12:49:53â€¯AM] Amir Ariff: â€œWorld Wide Web created because the creator malas asyik kena bawak PC kalau nak share filesâ€

ğŸ˜„ Funny and semi-true!
The real reason:
The World Wide Web was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989 while working at CERN. His goal was to make it easier for researchers to share and access documents across different computers.

So your version â€” â€œmalas nak bawak PCâ€ â€” is a fun, simplified (and Malaysianized) way of saying:

â€œHe wanted a more convenient way to share files.â€
âœ… Creative but not inaccurate.
